thread.section_title: Midlands Sport News - West Midlands Sport - Sports News Scores « Express & Star
thread.title: Pictures: Kidderminster 0 Southport 1

title: Pictures: Kidderminster 0 Southport 1
text:
The result left rock-bottom Harriers still searching for their first win of the season, after losing 10 and drawing eight of their opening 18 matches. 
Southport, two places above Kidderminster, clinched victory with an 83rd-minute goal from former Aggborough campaigner Andy Bishop. TEAM LINE-UPS Calvin Dinsley V S: Andy Wright. 
Kidderminster: Snedkner; Hodgkiss, Rowe-Turner, Langmead, Young; Maxwell, Whitfield, Dinsley; Murphy (Styche 58), Hassan, Francis-Angol. 
Subs not used: Palmer, Tunnicliffe, Campbell, Forsyth. 
Southport: Crocombe; Challoner, Foster, Wright, Davies; Almond, Jones, Joyce, Nolan; Stockton (Phenix 62, Rutherford 87), Bishop. 
Subs not used: Viscosi, Thompson, Blakeman. 
Referee: Derek Eaton (Gloucs). 
Attendance: 1,593 (89 away fans). 
Harriers are now eight points away from safety and will be desperate to end their grim winless run when they visit Stourbridge on Saturday for an eagerly-awaited FA Cup fourth qualifying round clash. 
Their hopes of opening their victory account against the Sandgrounders looked a possibility at times, but luck deserted them during the first-half when new-boy Ben Whitfield had two efforts strike the woodwork. 
They also failed to take their chances in the second period, particularly on 69 minutes when substitute Reece Styche’s ball control let him down when he was in an excellent position to break the deadlock. 
Harriers’ failure to find the net made it a frustrating afternoon for head coach Dave Hockaday, who felt his new-look side had not deserved to lose. 
He added: “All the old football sayings come to mind and I’m really scratching my head to wonder how we’ve lost that game. But we have and we’ve got to take it on the chin. 
“We’ve got to keep believing, because nobody is going to feel sorry for us and we don’t expect that.” 
Harriers lost their two games against Southport by a similar scoreline last season. 
But they did produce a first-half display which suggested they were capable of securing their first win since triumphing 3-1 at home to Braintree Town on March 28. 
On 27 minutes, they went perilously close to nudging ahead when the eye-catching Whitfield fired in a curling shot which rebounded off a post. 
Nine minutes later, luck deserted him again when the midfielder’s first-time shot, following a teasing cross from captain Jared Hodgkiss, smacked against the bar. More on this story:
